p.seg: Chapter 1: Learning and Conduct
To learn and then practice is the highest level;
to learn and then speak of it is the next level;
to learn and then teach it to others is yet another level down;
to have none of these is to be just one of the crowd.
Someone asked:
"People admire longevity,
hoping to use it for learning;
can they be said to be fond of learning?"
I replied:
"They are not truly fond of it;
true learning doesn't admire."
Is the Way of Heaven not embodied in Zhongni (Confucius)?
Zhongni was a driver who explained (the Way);
is it not in these Confucians here?
If they intend to re-explain what he said,
it would be better to give these Confucians golden mouths and wooden tongues.
Someone asked:
"Learning is useless;
what about one's innate qualities?"
I replied:
"You haven't thought about it deeply enough.
Those who have knives sharpen them;
those who have jade polish it;
if they are not sharpened or polished,
What use is it?
Sharpen it and polish it;
the substance is within it.
Otherwise, stop."
The son of a moth
is killed, and it encounters a wasp,
which prays over it, saying:
"Be like me, be like me."
After a long time, it will resemble it.
How quickly! The seventy disciples resembled Zhongni (Confucius).
To govern with learning,
to refine it with thought,
to sharpen it with friends,
to exalt it with reputation,
to complete it with diligence,
can be called truly loving learning.
Confucius learned from the Duke of Zhou,
Yan Yuan learned from Confucius,
Yi and Feng Meng shared his bow,
Liang gave up his plan,
Ban threw away his axe
and learned from them.
Who says it's wrong?
Someone says:
"This is fame, that is fame;
just stay in one."
It said:
"Rivers have their *du*,
mountains have their *yue*;
those that are high and large,
are what the multitude cannot cross."
Someone asked:
"The world speaks of casting metal,
can metal be cast?"
It said:
"I have heard that
when encountering a gentleman, one asks about casting people,
not about casting metal."
Someone said:
"Can people be cast?"
It said:
"Confucius cast Yan Yuan."
Someone abruptly said:
"How profound!
Asking about casting metal, one obtains [the answer about] casting people."
Learning is
the means by which to cultivate one's nature.
Sight, hearing, speech, appearance, thought—
these are what nature possesses.
Learning makes them correct;
otherwise, they are evil.
Teachers! Teachers!
[They are] the lifeblood of the *tong* tree.
Devoting oneself to seeking a teacher is better than merely devoting oneself to learning.
A teacher
is a model for people.
If the model is not a model,
if the standard is not a standard,
then shortcomings will be plentiful.
In a bustling marketplace,
one cannot prevail against dissenting opinions;
with a single book,
one cannot prevail against differing interpretations.
For a bustling marketplace,
one must establish a balance;
for a single book,
one must establish a teacher.
Practice, practice!
If practicing leads to overcoming right with wrong,
how much more so will practicing lead to overcoming wrong with right?
Alas!
The student should carefully examine what is right.
Someone might say:
"How does one know what is right and then practice it?"
I say:
"Look at the sun and the moon and you will know the insignificance of the stars;
look up to the sages and you will know the pettiness of the many theories."
Learning, as a matter for kings,
has been around for a long time.
Yao, Shun, Yu, Tang, Wen, and Wu were all diligent and earnest,
Confucius was constantly concerned and active.
It has been a long time since their era.
Someone asked about "progress."
He said: "Water."
Someone asked: "Is it because it does not cease day or night?"
He said: "Is that so?
Is it not water that fills up and then gradually overflows?"
Someone asked about "gradual progress" (鴻漸, referring to the I Ching hexagram).
He said: "Not because it goes or does not go,
not because it resides or does not reside,
gradual progress is just like water!"
"May I ask about the gradual progress of wood?"
He said:
"That which stops at the bottom and gradually rises to the top, that is wood!
It is just like water."
I have never seen one who uses an axe and adze on his virtue as one uses an axe and adze on a roof beam.
Birds and beasts are those who are moved by their emotions,
common people are different from them!
The worthy are different from the common people,
the sages are different from the worthy.
The creation of ritual and righteousness has a reason.
If a man does not study,
even if he has no worries,
how is he different from a bird or beast?
Learning is the way to strive to become a junzi (gentleman).
There are those who seek and do not obtain,
but there has never been one who obtained without seeking.
To emulate a Ji horse
is also to ride a Ji horse.
To emulate a Yan person
is also to be a follower of Yan.
Someone might say, "Is it easy to become a follower of Yan?"
I say,
"If you emulate him, then it is."
Someone says,
"In the past, Yan once emulated the Master,
Zheng Kaofu once emulated Yin Jifu,
and Gongzi Xisi once emulated Zheng Kaofu.
If one does not wish to emulate, then so be it,
but if one wishes to emulate, who can prevent it?"
Someone might say, "The Books and the Classics are the same, but the world does not value them. Is it permissible to study them?"
I say, "It is permissible."
Someone laughs silently and says, "You must use strategies and decisions to determine success."
I say, "The learning of a great man is for the Way;
the learning of a petty man is for profit.
Are you doing it for the Way? Or for profit?"
Someone says, "If one plows and does not harvest, hunts and does not feast, does one still plow and hunt?"
I say, "If one plows the Way and obtains the Way, hunts virtue and obtains virtue, that is already harvesting and feasting.
I do not see the stars Shen and Chen facing each other."
Therefore, the gentleman values moving towards goodness.
One who moves towards goodness is a follower of the sage!
A hundred rivers learn from the sea and reach the sea;
Approaching hills with the aim of learning about mountains, but not actually reaching the mountains,
this is why I dislike those who merely draw pictures (i.e., those who only scratch the surface).
Parties gathering repeatedly are worse than jackdaws (鸒斯),
they only harm food supplies.
Friends who are not sincere are merely friends in appearance;
companions who are not sincere are merely companions in appearance.
Someone said,
"Your management of property is not as wealthy as Dan Gui."
He replied, "I have heard that when teachers speak with each other,
they discuss benevolence and righteousness;
when people in the marketplace speak with each other,
they discuss wealth and profit.
If it’s wealth! If it’s wealth!"
Someone said,
"When you are alive, you have nothing with which to support yourself;
when you are dead, you have nothing with which to bury yourself;
what about that?"
He replied, "Using what one has to provide sustenance,
this is the utmost of sustenance;
using what one has to provide burial,
this is the utmost of burial."
Someone said,
"Yi Dun's wealth, used to practice filial piety,
isn't that the utmost?
Yan Hui was hungry!"
He replied,
"He emphasizes the coarse,
Yan emphasizes the refined;
He emphasizes the crooked,
Yan emphasizes the upright.
Is Yan inferior?
Is Yan inferior?"
Someone said:
"If I were to wear vermilion cords and hold gold,
the joy would be immeasurable."
It was said:
"The joy of wearing vermilion cords and holding gold is not as great as the joy of the son of Yan.
The joy of the son of Yan is internal;
the joy of wearing vermilion cords and holding gold is external."
Someone said:
"May I ask about the interior of repeated emptiness?"
It was said: "Yan is not boastful;
even if he obtained the world, it would not be enough to bring him joy."
"But is there also suffering?"
It was said: "Yan suffers from Confucius's towering excellence."
Someone was startled and said:
"This suffering is precisely the source of his joy!"
It was said: "In establishing the Way and teaching, there is no one to stop Zhongni (Confucius);
In learning skills and achieving accomplishments, there is no one to stop Yan Yuan."
Someone said:
"Establishing the Way, Zhongni
cannot be contemplated on.
Skills and accomplishments, Yan Yuan
cannot be forced upon."
Someone asked:
"You have not thought about it.
If you think about it, what can stop you?"
Volume 2 of Wuzi
Someone asked, "Wuzi was fond of writing fu (rhapsodies) when he was young."
He said, "Yes.
A child carves insects and seals."
After a while, he said:
"A grown man does not do it."
Someone asked, "Can fu be used for satire?"
He said, "Satire? If it is satire, then fine;
if not, I fear it will inevitably turn into exhortation."
Someone said, "The brocade of mist and fine silk is beautiful."
He said, "It is a moth in women's work."
In the "Essay on Swordsmen" it says:
"A sword can be used to cherish oneself."
He said, "Does a prison make people more polite?"
Someone asked, "Are the fu of Jing Cha, Tang Le, Song Yu, and Mei Cheng beneficial?"
He said, "They must be lewd."
"If they are lewd, what can be done?"
He said, "The fu of poets are beautiful and follow principles;
the fu of literati are beautiful and lewd.
If the school of Confucius were to employ fu,
then Jia Yi would ascend the hall,
and Sima Xiangru would enter the inner chamber.
If they were not employed, what then?"
Someone asked about "flies, red and purple."
He said, "Clear seeing."
Asked about the similarity between the music of Zheng and Wei.
He said, "Sharp hearing."
Someone said, "Zhu and Kuang are not succeeded through generations,
what can be done?"
He said, "Just be diligent in refining it."
Someone asked, "Mixing the five tones and twelve pitches,
sometimes refined, sometimes Zheng,
why is that?"
He said, "If it is centered and upright, it is refined;
if it is excessively flamboyant, it is Zheng."
"May I ask about the foundation?"
He said, "The Yellow Bell generates it,
centering and uprightness pacifies it,
then surely the music of Zheng and Wei cannot enter!"
Someone said, "Women have allure,
do books also have allure?"
He said, "They do.
Women detest gaudy rouge and cinnabar that obscures their beauty,
books detest lewd words that corrupt the rules and measures."
Someone asked,
"Was Qu Yuan wise?"
He said, "Like jade, like crystal,
he changed into vermillion and blue.
How wise he was! How wise he was!"
Someone asked,
"Does a gentleman value rhetoric?"
He said,
The gentleman values substance in his endeavors.
If substance exceeds rhetoric, it becomes obstinate;
if rhetoric exceeds substance, it becomes mere embellishment;
if substance and rhetoric are balanced, it becomes principled.
To be sufficient in speech and ample in countenance
is the elegance of virtue.
Someone asked:
"Gongsun Long used tens of thousands of sophistical arguments
as a standard.
Is this a standard?"
The answer was:
"Cutting wood to make chess pieces,
and stuffing leather to make a ball,
also have their standards.
But that which does not accord with the standards of the Former Kings,
the gentleman does not take as a standard."
Reading books is like viewing mountains and rivers.
Ascending Mount Tai, one knows the dwarfishness of all other mountains.
How much more so a small hill?
Floating on the vast ocean, one knows the foulness of rivers.
How much more so a dried-up swamp?
To abandon ships and rafts and cross small ditches is foolish.
To abandon the *Five Classics* and seek to cross to the Way is foolish.
To discard common delicacies and crave exotic dishes
one will hardly perceive true flavor.
To forsake the Great Sage and favor the various masters
one will hardly perceive the true Way.
The paths in the mountain ravines,
are too many to travel;
the doors facing the wall,
are too many to enter.
Someone said: "How can one enter?"
Someone answered: "Through Confucius.
Confucius is like a door."
Someone asked: "Are you a door?"
Someone answered: "A door indeed! A door indeed!
Only I am not just a door."
Someone wanted to study the *Cangjie* and *Shipian* texts.
Someone said: "Scribe indeed! Scribe indeed!
It's better than recklessly leaving gaps."
Someone said:
"There is a person,
who claims his surname is Kong and his given name is Zhongni.
Enter his gate, ascend his hall,
lean on his desk, wear his clothes,
can he then be called Zhongni?"
Someone answered: "His outward appearance is right,
but his essence is not."
"May I ask about the essence?"
Someone answered: "He has the essence of a sheep but the skin of a tiger;
he rejoices upon seeing grass,
he fights upon seeing a jackal,
forgetting his tiger skin.
The Sage is distinct like a tiger,
his outward appearance is brilliant.
The gentleman's transformation is like the leopard's changing spots;
its patterns become splendid.
The debater's transformation is like the wildcat's changing markings;
its patterns become dense.
The wildcat transforms into a leopard;
the leopard transforms into a tiger.
To love books but not test them against Zhongni (Confucius) is to be a book repository.
It is a book warehouse.
To love speaking but not test it against Zhongni is to be a peddler of words.
It is a talking bell (a noisy but empty thing).
The gentleman's speech is without picking and choosing;
his listening is without excess.
Picking and choosing leads to chaos;
excess leads to deviation.
There are those who describe the correct way and slightly deviate from it;
but there has never been one who describes deviation and slightly corrects it.
The way of Confucius,
its standards are quite simple and easy!
Someone says:
"If one learns it from childhood,
it becomes like white powder (insipid),
how can its standards be simple and easy?"
I say:
"It means not being deceitful about deceit,
not being fraudulent about fraud.
If one is deceitful about deceit and fraudulent about fraud,
Though one has ears and eyes,
how can one rectify [them]?"
With much hearing, one should guard it with brevity;
with much seeing, one should guard it with clarity.
Little hearing leads to no brevity,
little seeing leads to no clarity.
With three hundred green robes,
what does the color matter?
With three thousand ramie floss wadding,
what does the cold matter?
The way of the gentleman has four easinesses:
simple and easy to use;
concise and easy to maintain;
clear and easy to see;
lawful and easy to speak of.
When violent winds level rain,
then one knows that the summer house serves as a shelter;
when oppressive government oppresses the world,
then one knows that the sage serves as a protective wall.
In ancient times, the doctrines of Yang and Mo blocked the way,
Mencius refuted and dispelled them,
making the way wide open.
Later, there were those who blocked the way,
presumptuously comparing themselves to Mencius.
Someone asked:
"Everyone affirms what they affirm and denies what they deny,
who then will be able to correct them?"
I replied: "When all things are confused, we look to the heavens for guidance;
when all words are in disarray, we turn to the sages for judgment."
Someone asked:
"How can we see the sages to turn to them for judgment?"
I replied: "When they are alive, we have the people;
when they are gone, we have the books;
these are unified."
Chapter Three: Cultivating Oneself
Cultivate yourself as a bow,
correct your thoughts as arrows,
establish righteousness as the target.
Take aim, then release.
The release will surely hit the mark.
Human nature is a mixture of good and evil.
Cultivate the good and you become a good person,
cultivate the evil and you become an evil person.
Is Qi [vital energy]
what guides the horses of good and evil?
Someone asked:
"Confucius had many affairs,
but he was not employed.
Was he then diligent and worried?"
I replied: "The sage delights in Heaven and understands destiny.
"If one is content with fate, then one will not be diligent;
if one knows destiny, then one will not worry."
Someone asked about "inscriptions."
He said, "Inscriptions! Inscriptions!
They are intended to encourage caution."
The words of a sage
can be put into practice;
to make people believe them
is what cannot be done.
Therefore, the gentleman strives to learn and diligently practices.
He values his goods before trading them,
he cultivates his person before associating with others,
he perfects his plans before acting—
this is the path to accomplishment.
What the gentleman is cautious about:
speech, propriety, and writing.
In associating with superiors, do not flatter;
in associating with inferiors, do not be arrogant;
then one can accomplish something.
Someone said, "The gentleman guards himself;
why does he need to associate with others?"
He said, "When Heaven and Earth interact, all things are born;
when people interact, meritorious achievements are made.
Why only guard oneself?"
To love greatness but not act on it,
How great is it;
to aspire to great heights but not act,
how high is it really?
Looking up at the celestial court, one knows the world's dwelling is low!
The talent of Gongyizi and Dong Zhongshu was such that
if they were unable to see goodness clearly,
and their minds were not firm,
could they have been matched?
Someone asked
about the use of "benevolence, righteousness, propriety, wisdom, and trustworthiness."
He said:
"Benevolence is a dwelling.
Righteousness is a road.
Propriety is clothing.
Wisdom is a candle.
Trustworthiness is a tally.
Dwelling in the house,
following the road,
wearing proper clothing,
lighting the candle,
holding the tally,
the gentleman does not move rashly;
when he moves, he succeeds."
There is intent there!
Mencius said:
"There are those who have intention and do not succeed,
but there has never been one who achieved it without intention."
Someone asked about "cultivating oneself."
I replied: "Cultivate oneself according to Zhongni (Confucius)."
Someone said: "To cultivate oneself according to Zhongni,
wouldn't Zhongni then be too sparse (lacking)?!"
I replied: "To guide a horse with a Ji (a famous fine horse),
Someone said: "In a field, weeds grow tall;
thinking of someone far away, the heart is anxious."
I replied: "The sun has light, the moon has brightness.
If one does not look at the sun for three years, one's vision will surely be blind;
if one does not look at the moon for three years, one's spirit will surely be dim.
The ethereal soul will be desolate and barren,
the essence of spirit will be desolate and sunk,
groping for the path with a clod of earth,
one will merely be walking in the dark."
Someone asked: "What constitutes a person?"
I replied: "Embrace the four heavy things, discard the four light things,
then one can be called a person."
He said:
"What are the four heavy things?"
I replied: "Weighty words, weighty actions, weighty appearance, weighty preferences.
If words are weighty, then there is principle;
if actions are weighty, then there is virtue;
if appearance is weighty, then there is dignity;
if preferences are weighty, then there is observation (discernment)."
"I dare ask about the four light things."
I replied:
"If words are light, then one invites worry;
Conduct that is frivolous invites trouble;
demeanor that is frivolous invites disgrace;
and affection that is frivolous invites lewdness."
The *Rites* are full of ceremonies.
Someone said, "If one does not eat meat after midday,
the meat will surely become dry;
isn't that acceptable?"
if one does not drink wine after midday,
the wine will surely become sour.
With the host and guest bowing hundreds of times while wine goes through three rounds,
isn't that excessive?"
He replied, "If there is no substance to the display, it is boorish;
if there is display without substance, it is false;
if display and substance match, that is ritual."
The abundance of the mountain female (a type of offering),
is the intent understood?
Someone said, "Yan Hui's bamboo basket and gourd,
how could he be so emaciated?"
He replied, "When clarity is above (i.e., a wise ruler),
the hundred officials have cattle and sheep; this too is mountain female.
When darkness is above (i.e., a foolish ruler),
using a bamboo basket and gourd to pull up roots, this too is mountain female.
How could he be emaciated?
The lightness of a thousand *jun* (weight),
is due to Wu Huo's strength;
the joy of a bamboo basket and gourd,
is due to Yan's virtue."
Someone asked:
"Is there any difference between the hide of a plow ox and the hide of a black-red ox?"
He said, "The same."
"If that's the case, then why not plow with it?"
He said, "Because I intend to show filial piety to ghosts and spirits,
I dare not use that plow for that purpose.
It's like slaughtering sheep and sticking pigs,
dismissing guests and rewarding the army,
what's the difference between plowing and not plowing then!"
A virtuous person is fond of asking questions of the sage.
Someone asked:
"The people of Lu have little virtue,
why is it said they are fond of asking questions of Zhong Ni (Confucius)?"
He said:
"It's precisely because Lu has not become fond of asking questions of Zhong Ni.
If they were fond of asking questions of Zhong Ni,
then Lu would have become Eastern Zhou."
Someone asked:
"If a person leans against Confucius' wall,
plays the music of Zheng and Wei,
and recites the books of Han Fei and Zhuangzi,
should we bring him inside the gate?"
He said:
"If he were a barbarian, then bring him in,
if he's leaning against the gate, then wave him away.
It's a pity that the robe was not finished and turned into a skirt."
A sage's ear does not heed what is wrong,
his mouth does not become proficient in good;
a worthy man's ear chooses, his mouth chooses;
the multitude has no choice.
Someone asked about "the masses."
The reply: "They are born of wealth and status."
"[What about] the worthy?"
The reply: "Righteousness."
"[What about] the sage?"
The reply: "Spirit."
By observing the worthy, one can understand the masses.
By observing the sage, one can understand the worthy.
By observing Heaven and Earth, one can understand the sage.
The world has three kinds of preferences:
The masses prefer others to follow them.
The worthy prefer others to correct them.
The sage prefers others to be his teachers.
The world has three kinds of standards:
The masses use family standards.
The worthy use national standards.
The sage uses the standards of the entire world.
The world has three gates:
If one proceeds from emotion and desire,
one enters through the animal gate.
If one proceeds from ritual and righteousness,
one enters through the human gate.
If one proceeds from solitary wisdom,
one enters through the sage's gate.
Someone asked:
"What kind of scholar can cultivate himself for peace?"
The reply:
"Its being centered is vast and profound,
its being outwardly respectful and concise,
then one can nourish the self."
The superior man is subtle and cautious in his virtue,
regrets and reproaches will not arrive,
what cause for resentment or confusion will there be?
The superior man's ears are instructed by virtue,
the inferior man's ears obey his own desires.
One whose words are not shameful and whose actions are not disgraceful,
Confucius was wary of him.
Inquiry into the Way, Volume Four
Someone asked about "the Way."
It was said:
"The Way is that which is unobstructed,
there is nothing it does not penetrate."
Someone asked:
"Can one deviate from it?"
It was said:
"To follow Yao, Shun, King Wen is the correct Way,
that which is not Yao, Shun, King Wen is a different Way,
the superior man is correct and does not deviate."
Someone asked about "the Way."
It was said:
"The Way is like a road, like a river,
carts and boats flow continuously,
without ceasing day and night."
Someone asked:
"How can one obtain the straight path and follow it?"
I replied:
"Even if a road is winding, if it leads to all the Xia (Chinese states), then follow it.
Even if a river is winding, if it flows into the sea, then follow it."
Someone asked:
"Even if a matter is circuitous, if it leads to the sages,
should it be followed?"
Dao, De, Ren, Yi, and Li,
are they analogous to the body?
Dao guides,
De obtains,
Ren embodies humanity,
Yi is appropriate,
Li embodies them all—
this is nature.
When united, they are whole;
when separated, they are scattered.
If one person can comprehensively govern these four elements,
their body will be complete!
Someone asked about "De being manifested."
I replied: "Without knowing
the creation, the top creates the bottom."
Please explain "without knowing."
I replied:
"If one practices ritual there,
and the people benefit here,
how would they know?"
Someone asked,
"What about having virtue without ritual propriety?"
He replied,
"Ritual propriety is the embodiment (of virtue).
If a person is without ritual propriety,
how can he be considered to have virtue?"
Someone asked about "Heaven."
He said,
"From Heaven,
I see doing through non-doing!"
Someone asked,
"Isn't it Heaven
that carves and shapes all forms?"
He replied, "It is precisely because it does not carve.
If it were like things, things that are carved and shaped,
how could it have the strength to supply them all?"
Laozi's words on Dao and De,
I find some value in.
But when he emphasizes rejecting benevolence and righteousness,
and abolishing ritual propriety and learning,
I find no value in them.
How can I attain enlightenment?
Only a sage can attain enlightenment;
others are insignificant.
How great is the sage,
his words are of the utmost importance!
Open them, and one sees the world clearly;
Close it, and with a *peng* sound, one cannot see what is inside the wall.
The words of a sage
are like water and fire.
Someone asked, "What about water and fire?"
He said:
"Water, the more you measure it, the deeper it becomes;
the more you exhaust it, the farther it extends.
Fire, the more you use it, the brighter it becomes;
the longer it dwells, the stronger it grows."
To govern the world effectively,
without relying on ritual and the Five Teachings,
then I would consider the Yellow Emperor, Yao, and Shun to be superfluous growths.
Someone said:
"The highest form of governance is without law,
for law is not the means of governing."
He said:
"In the age of primordial chaos,
the sages abhorred it,
and thus law began with Fuxi and was completed with Yao.
If it were not Fuxi or Yao,
and ritual and propriety were merely clamoring noises,
the sages would not adopt them."
Someone asked:
"The rituals of all the regions,
ritual and music, which is right?"
He said:
"Yin ruled using the Central States."
Someone asked:
"What constitutes the Central States?"
I reply:
"That upon which the five administrations are applied,
and which is nourished by the seven taxes,
that which is central to Heaven and Earth,
constitutes the Central States.
Beyond this, what lies ahead, are they still human?"
When a sage governs the world,
he regulates them with ritual and music.
Without them, they are beasts;
different, they are barbarians.
I have seen the lesser ritual and music of the various philosophers,
but I have not seen the lesser ritual and music of the sages.
Who has writing that does not come from a brush,
or speech that does not come from the tongue?
I see that the constant of Heaven serves as the brush and tongue of the emperors and kings.
Wisdom, that is to know.
If wisdom is
employed when it should not be,
or increased when it should not be,
then it is not merely superfluous but detrimental.
If one deeply understands the making of instruments, vehicles, and buildings,
then ritual arises from oneself.
Someone asked about "Great Sound."
I replied:
"Not thunder, not lightning,
A low and rumbling sound,
Growing fuller over time,
Embodied in all the sages."
Someone asked:
"Does the Way have cause and effect, or not?"
I replied:
"If it is fitting, then it is cause and effect;
If it is not, then it is reform."
Someone asked about "Non-Action."
I replied: "What is the meaning of 'non-action'?
In the past, Yu and Xia, inheriting Yao's position,
Practiced Yao's Way,
Laws and standards were clear,
Rituals and music were established,
They folded their hands and watched the prosperity of the people under heaven;
That was non-action.
Succeeding Jie, continuing after Zhou,
Laws and standards were abandoned,
Rituals and music were deficient,
Sitting idle and watching the people under heaven die,
Is that non-action?"
Someone asked:
"In the ancient times, the common people's eyes and ears
Only saw and heard.
What is seen is difficult to conceal,
"Once heard, it is difficult to block."
He said:
"Heaven, in its creation, brought forth the people,
causing them to see with their eyes and hear with their ears.
Therefore, there is ritual in seeing
and music in hearing.
If seeing is without ritual
and hearing is without music,
even though there are people,
how can they be led aright?"
Someone asked about "new" and "worn."
He said:
"If it is new, then follow it;
if it is worn, then add to or subtract from it."
Someone asked:
"In the Great Antiquity, virtue was embraced,
not ritual.
Infants long for,
foals and calves follow;
how could there be ritual?"
He said:
"Infants and calves!
Infants and calves are embraced by their mothers, not their fathers.
The mother's embrace is love,
the father's embrace is respect.
To have only a mother and not a father
is not as good as the excellence of both parents."
A family of schemers said:
"Using deceptive schemes,
to subdue the enemy's army without fighting,
that is the way of Yao and Shun."
Someone said:
"To subdue the enemy's army without fighting,
that is the way of Yao and Shun?
With sweat soaking the nape and dampening the lapel,
is that the way of Yao and Shun?
To display jade but sell stone,
is that not deception?"
Someone asked:
"Deception and ruin,
which is better?"
He said:
"Ruin is better."
Someone said:
"If you were to command the six armies,
whom would you employ?"
He said:
"If one governs according to the proper way,
then all the world's deceivers can be put to use;
if one governs contrary to the proper way,
then all the world's deceivers will become enemies.
Therefore, he who possesses the empire
should be cautious in his governance."
Someone asked:
"To awe the feudal lords, is military conquest necessary?
It is the power of deception.
If it were lost!"
Someone said:
"To awe the feudal lords, one must rely on cunning and deception,
that's acceptable.
It's not as good as awing the feudal lords
without needing cunning and deception."
Someone said:
"Without cunning and deception,
how will you conquer?"
He replied:
"Even if one is forced to conquer,
isn't there the *Sima Fa* [military manual]?
Why must one resort to cunning and deception!"
The techniques of Shen Buhai and Han Fei [legalist philosophers]
are the height of inhumanity.
How are they different from using people like cattle and sheep?
If people are used like cattle and sheep,
then wouldn't foxes, mole crickets, and earthworms not be sacrificed in the winter solstice rituals?"
Someone said:
"If a knife is not sharp,
a writing brush is not pointed,
isn't it acceptable to sharpen them on a whetstone?"
He replied:
"If people are whetstones, then the Qin dynasty is still in power."
Someone said:
"Are punishments and titles not part of the Way?
Why are they considered natural?"
He replied:
"Why necessarily use punishments and laws?
Playing Weiqi (围棋, Go),
swordsmanship,
animosity, and illusions
are all natural as well.
That which is great, makes the correct path;
that which is small, makes the treacherous path."
Someone asked:
"Are the laws of Shen Buhai and Han Fei not laws?"
He replied:
"Law refers to
the laws of Tang, Yu, Cheng, and Zhou.
As for Shen Buhai and Han Fei! As for Shen Buhai and Han Fei!"
If Zhuang Zhou, Shen Buhai, and Han Fei
are not different from the sages
and are gradually included in the writings,
then what will become of the descendants of the Yan family and the grandsons of the Min family?
What will become of them?
Someone asked:
"Does Zhuang Zhou have any merit?"
He replied:
"Few desires."
"Does Zou Yan have any merit?"
He replied:
"Self-restraint.
By the time of the Zhou Dynasty, there was no longer the righteousness between ruler and subject,
and Zou Yan was ignorant of the space between heaven and earth,
even though neighbors, they do not see each other."
Inquiry on Spirits, Scroll Five
Someone asked about "Spirits."
I said, "It is the mind."
"Please explain it."
I said, "It is hidden in Heaven, yet it is Heaven;
it is hidden in Earth, yet it is Earth.
It is Heaven and Earth, spirits and brightness, yet it cannot be fathomed.
The mind's hiddenness is such that one can still attempt to fathom it,
how much more so with people?
How much more so with human affairs and relationships?"
"May I ask about the hidden mind of a sage?"
I said, "In the past, Zhongni (Confucius) hid his mind in King Wen,
and comprehended him.
Yan Yuan also hid his mind in Zhongni,
and was only a hair's breadth away from comprehending him completely.
The spirit resides in what it is hidden within."
The spirit of Heaven is Heaven's brightness,
illuminating and knowing the four directions.
The essence of Heaven is Heaven's purity,
from which all things originate and categorize themselves.
Is the human mind its spirit?
Hold onto it, and it remains;
release it, and it is lost.
Those who can constantly hold onto it and preserve it, are only the sages!
Sages preserve their spirit and seek ultimate truth,
To bring about the great harmony of the world,
to achieve the great benefit of the world,
to harmonize the relationship between heaven and man, making them without separation.
When the dragon is coiled in the mud,
the snake will be rampant.
Oh, snake, oh, snake,
how can you understand the ambition of the dragon!
Someone asks, "Does the dragon necessarily want to fly to heaven?"
I say, "When the time is right to fly, then it flies;
when the time is right to hide, then it hides.
It both flies and hides,
it eats only what is appropriate,
and its form cannot be controlled!"
Someone says, "If the sage is not controlled,
then why was he in Youli?"
I say, "The dragon is a dragon because it is not controlled,
and the sage is a sage because he does not act impulsively."
Someone asks, "Can the classics be added to or subtracted from?"
I say,
"The *Book of Changes* began with the eight trigrams,
and King Wen expanded it to sixty-four;
its addition is knowable.
The *Book of Poetry*,
the *Book of Documents*,
the *Book of Rites*, and the *Spring and Autumn Annals*,
were either inherited or created,
and were completed by Confucius;
Its benefit can be known.
Therefore, the Way is not natural
but is created in response to the times;
its decrease and increase can be known."
Someone said: "The *Book of Changes* (*Yijing*) loses one part;
even the foolish know that something is missing.
As for the *Book of Documents* (*Shangshu*), more than half is incomplete,
and those who study it do not know.
What a pity that the preface to the *Book of Documents* is not as good as that to the *Book of Changes*!"
I replied:
"That is a matter of numbers;
it can be counted, hence it is so.
As for the preface to the *Book of Documents*,
even Confucius could do nothing about it."
In the past, those who interpreted the *Book of Documents* arranged them in hundreds,
but the chapter "Wine Announcement" (*Jiugao*) suddenly disappeared.
It is lost now.
The *Documents* of the Yu
and Xia dynasties are turbid,
the *Documents* of the Shang dynasty are vast,
the *Documents* of the Zhou dynasty are stern.
As for the later Zhou,
their *Documents* are paltry!
Someone asked: "Should the classics of the sages not be made easy to understand?"
I replied:
"No.
If Heaven could be measured quickly,
Then its capacity to cover things is shallow.
If the earth can be measured in a short time,
then its capacity to bear things is thin.
How great!
Heaven and earth are the outer wall for the myriad things,
and the *Five Classics* are the inner wall for the various theories."
Someone asked, "The actions of the sages,
can they not be as clear as the sun and moon?
Why is there so much contention in later generations!"
I said:
"Blind Kuang could be silent,
but Blind Kuang could not regulate ears that were unevenly attuned;
Di Ya could make sounds,
but Di Ya could not regulate mouths that were unevenly attuned."
The words of a gentleman,
obscure, must have verification in the clear;
distant, must have verification in the near;
great, must have verification in the small;
subtle, must have verification in the obvious.
To speak without verification is called recklessness.
Are gentlemen reckless? They are not reckless.
If words cannot express one's heart,
and books cannot express one's words,
how difficult it is!
Only the sage obtains the understanding of words
and grasps the essence of books.
The white sun illuminates them,
The Jiang and the He [rivers] are used to cleanse things,
vast and expansive, it is impossible to resist them!
Meeting face to face,
words fitting appropriately,
expressing what the heart desires,
conveying the anxieties of people,
nothing is better than speech.
Encompassing the affairs of the world,
recording the long-past and illuminating the distant,
clarifying the obscurity of ancient times,
transmitting the diligent efforts across thousands of miles,
nothing is better than writing.
Therefore, speech is the voice of the heart,
writing is the painting of the heart.
From voice and painting,
gentlemen and petty men are revealed.
Voice and painting,
are what moves the feelings of gentlemen and petty men?
The words of a sage,
are flowing like a river.
Those that follow it succeed,
those that go against it fail,
is it not like a river?
Someone asked: "Is Zhongni (Confucius) a sage?
Why could he not find a place in the world,
not even as good as Zeng Fan and Cai?"
I replied:
"Are sages [like] Fan and Cai?
Fan and Cai?
Cai.
If it were Fan, what would become of the Sage?"
Someone said:
"The Prince of Huainan and the Grand Historian,
are they very knowledgeable?
Why are their works so杂 (mixed, unsystematic)!"
I said:
"杂! 杂!
People are troubled because they consider much knowledge to be 杂,
but only the Sage considers it not 杂."
If a book is not canonical,
it is not a book;
if speech is not canonical,
it is not speech.
Speech and books that are not canonical,
much of it is superfluous.
Someone said:
"To transmit but not to create;
how then could the *Xuan* be created?"
I said:
"Its subject matter is transmitted,
but its writing is created."
One who cultivates but does not sprout,
he is my family's child, Wu!
At nine years old, he shares with me the text of the *Xuan*.
Someone asked:
"What is the purpose of the *Xuan* (Mysteries)?"
I (or He) replied:
"It is for benevolence and righteousness."
Someone asked:
"Who does not act benevolently?
Who does not act righteously?"
I (or He) replied:
"It is simply to not mix them with other things."
Someone asked about "the difficulty or ease of the Classics."
I (or He) replied:
"Preservation or extinction."
The person did not understand.
I (or He) said:
"If the person is preserved (i.e., has the proper understanding), then it is easy;
if the person is extinguished (i.e., lacks the proper understanding), then it is difficult.
Take Yanling Jizi's knowledge of music;
he was perhaps close to understanding!
If the music is loose (i.e., corrupt),
even if you have inscriptions on slips of wood, what can you do?
If, like the Zhou dynasty, rites and music, and all affairs are complete,
then everything can be considered not difficult.
If, like the Qin dynasty, rites and music, and all affairs are incomplete,
then everything can be considered difficult."
To have clothes but no skirt,
I do not know if that is acceptable;
to have a skirt but no clothes,
I do not know if that is acceptable.
Robes and skirts, how harmonious they are!
Someone asked about "Wen" (culture/civil virtue).
He replied:
"Order."
Asked about "Wu" (military/martial virtue).
He replied:
"Conquest."
The questioner had not understood.
He said:
"That affairs obtain their proper order is called 'Order';
overcoming one's selfishness is called 'Conquest.'"
To do something and have it result in action,
to move and have it result in glory,
that is virtue!
Someone said:
"Those who understand virtue are few;
how can it be glorious?"
He replied:
"I know it, so I do it;
even if others do not know me, I still do it,
its glory is great.
If I must be known before I do it,
the glory will be small."
Someone said:
"A gentleman is troubled by dying without a name;
why not rely on
prominent ministers, it may be possible."
He replied:
“How does a virtuous gentleman establish his reputation?
The rulers of Liang, Qi, Zhao, and Chu
were certainly wealthy and noble,
but how did they achieve renown?
Zheng Zizhen of Valley Mouth,
without compromising his will, tilled the land beneath the cliffs,
and his name shook the capital.
Could he be an official? Could he be an official!"
Someone asked about "people."
He said:
"It is difficult to know them."
He asked:
"What is difficult about it?"
He said:
"The difference between Mount Tai and an ant or an anthill,
the difference between the Yangtze and Yellow Rivers and a puddle,
is not difficult.
The difference between a great sage and a great charlatan
is difficult.
Alas!
To be able to distinguish between things that are similar is not difficult."
Someone asked:
"Is there anything to take from Zou Yan and Zhuang Zhou?"
He said:
"Take their virtues,
but not their faults."
"What are virtues and faults?"
He said:
Speaking of Heaven, Earth, and Man:
adhering to principles is virtue;
deviation is fault.
Faulty words, a gentleman does not utter them."
Book of Questions on Illumination, Volume Six
Someone asked about "Illumination."
The answer was:
"Subtle."
Someone asked:
"Subtle, how does it become illumination?"
The answer was:
"To see it in its subtlety,
does that obscure its contradictions?"
Is sagacity and clear perception the ultimate?
Without hearing, in truth, there are no ears;
Without illumination, in truth, there are no eyes.
May I ask about great sagacity and clear perception.
The answer was:
"Dizzying!
Only Heaven is sagacious,
Only Heaven is illuminating.
One who can raise his eyes high and lower his ears,
is it not Heaven?"
Someone asked:
"Knowing every small detail,
can one be called a teacher?"
The answer was:
"What kind of teacher is that!
What kind of teacher is that!
There is no lack of small matters in the world.
Knowing every one of them,
is that called a teacher?
The value of a teacher,
lies in knowing the great knowledge.
A teacher of small knowledge
is also of little worth."
Mencius passed by my door and did not enter my room.
Someone asked, "Does he perhaps despise me?"
He said,
"He picks my flowers but does not eat my fruit."
Someone said,
"Confucius was busy throughout his years,
surely Heaven wearied him
and made him ill?"
He said,
"Heaven did not only weary Confucius,
it also wearied itself.
Does Heaven get sick?
Heaven delights in Heaven,
and the sage delights in the sage."
Someone asked,
"Among birds there is the phoenix,
among beasts there is the unicorn.
Can all birds and beasts become phoenixes and unicorns?"
He said,
"Just as flocks of birds are to the phoenix,
and herds of beasts are to the unicorn,
it is a matter of form and nature.
How could the mass of people not be in relation to the sage?"
Someone said:
"How extreme!
The sage's Way is of no benefit to the mediocre.
The sage reads while the mediocre acts.
Why not get rid of it?"
I replied:
"How extreme!
Is your lack of understanding!
The sage reads and the mediocre acts,
and still something is learned.
To get rid of it is to wear away.
Those who wore away Qin,
were they not like this?
Throw it in the fire."
Someone asked:
"What should man value?"
I replied:
"Value wisdom."
He said:
"Many are those who use their wisdom to kill themselves.
Why value it?"
I replied:
"In the past, Gao Yao used his wisdom to formulate plans for the Emperor,
and those who killed themselves were far away;
Ji Zi, with his wisdom, presented the "Great Plan" to King Wu.
Those who forfeit their lives are far removed from it."
Zhong Ni (Confucius) was a sage,
yet perhaps he was inferior to Zi Gong in some respects.
Zi Gong declined and refined his understanding,
and then it became clear and expansive.
Alas!
Readers who deviate from Zi Gong's approach,
even if they read much,
what can they accomplish?
"How grand!
Tang the Successful greatly inherited [the mandate],
King Wen was profoundly excellent."
Someone asked about "greatly inherited."
I said:
"From small to great,
isn't that 'great' (丕 - pi)?
Overthrowing Xia by Heaven's will,
isn't that 'inherited' (承 - cheng)?"
"Profoundly excellent."
I said:
"Redoubling the six lines of the *Book of Changes*,
isn't that 'profound' (淵 - yuan)?
Gradually becoming bright and great,
isn't that 'excellent' (懿 - yi)?"
Someone asked about "fate."
I said:
"Fate,
is the decree of Heaven,
not caused by human effort.
Human effort is distinct from fate."
I ask, what is "human effort"?
He replied:
"It can cause existence or extinction,
it can cause life or death,
but this is not fate.
Fate cannot be avoided."
Someone said: "The son of the Yan family,
the grandson of the Ran family."
He replied:
"It is because they did not avoid (danger).
If one stands beneath a crumbling wall,
every movement invites sickness,
every step beckons death,
is that fate?
Is that fate!"
For the virtuous, fortune turns to misfortune;
for the wicked, misfortune turns to greater misfortune.
Time!
Time, why does it arrive so late,
and depart so quickly?
Gentlemen, strive for it!
Flattering words ruin customs,
To indulge in favoritism leads to the destruction of principles;
to tolerate evil leads to the destruction of virtue.
The superior man is careful in his words,
cautious in his affections,
and urgent in seizing the moment.
I have not seen a hurricane that can move the deaf and senseless.
Someone asked about the "superior man."
"When the country is well-governed,
he is like the phoenix;
when the country is in chaos,
he is like the phoenix."
Someone did not understand.
He said:
"He has not thought about it deeply."
He said:
"When the country is well-governed, he appears; when the country is in chaos, he hides.
The swan flies high in the dark sky,
what does the hunter desire?
The wren gathers selectively,
eating only what is clean;
the phoenix dances gracefully,
(but) not in the courtyard of Yao."
The dragon that is hidden or
ascends,
is his constancy advantageous?
Someone asked:
"How can a dragon be constant, advantageous, and successful?"
He said:
"When the time is not right, he hides,
is that not constancy? When the time is right, he ascends,
is that not advantageous?
Hiding or ascending depends on oneself.
using them according to the time,
is that not success?"
Someone asked about "preserving one's life."
He replied:
"Be discerning and wise."
Someone said: "Being simple and ignorant preserves life,
why then discerning and wise?"
He replied:
"What the gentleman values
is, moreover, using clarity
to protect and be careful with his person.
If, like a commoner, one acts blindly on a hidden path,
and survives by being rash,
the gentleman does not value that."
The purity of Gong Zhi of Chu,
how pure it is!
Zhuang of Shu was silent and profound.
The talent of Zhuang of Shu was precious;
he did not create superficial views,
nor pursue petty gains;
he remained secluded for a long time and did not change his integrity.
Even Sui and He could not surpass him in value.
To raise this to that height,
is it not precious?
I cherish Zhuangzi,
living in his way is difficult.
Not admiring wealth, one is then at peace.
What crafty desires would there be?
Someone asked: "Yao intended to cede the empire to Xu You,
and You was ashamed; is this true?"
I said:
"Those who love greatness do such things.
But You had no desires from the world.
Although he acknowledged the weight of Yao's sagacity and Shun's deliberation,
he still did not consider them greater than himself.
Loving greatness is exhausting and strenuous.
Chao Fu washing his ears,
is that not fitting?
The awe of the sacred place,
is it fitting to visit it at night?"
Vermilion birds
flutter about, returning to their roosts.
Someone asked: "Why take the vermilion bird as an example?"
I said:
"When the time comes, it comes;
when the time goes, it goes.
That which can come and go,
is that not what they call the vermilion bird?"
Someone asked: "Han Fei wrote the book "Shuo Nan" (On the Difficulties of Persuasion),
and yet ultimately died because of (the difficulties of) persuasion.
May I ask, what is the explanation for this contradiction?"
I said:
"The difficulty of persuasion, that is precisely why he died!"
He said:
"Why is that?"
I said:
"A gentleman acts according to propriety,
stops according to righteousness, advances when in harmony,
and retreats when not;
confident and not worried about disharmony.
To persuade others while worrying about disharmony
means there's nothing one wouldn't do."
Someone said,
"Is not being unsuccessful in persuasion a cause for worry?"
He said,
"Persuading without adhering to the Way is cause for worry;
adhering to the Way but still being unsuccessful is not cause for worry."
Someone asked about "wisdom."
He said,
"To extensively understand one's thoughts."
Someone asked about
"conduct."
He said,
"To extensively embody one's virtue."
Sparsity of Knowledge, Scroll Seven
I rarely see people who like to borrow.
Looking to what is near in writing,
Words that are near and pleasing to the ear,
if false, will turn away from what is right.
Someone might say: "Why is it so extreme?
The way of the former kings fills our gate."
I reply:
“It cannot be helped;
if it could be stopped, it would have been stopped already.
Those who can stop it but do not,
are few indeed!"
To eagerly devote one's heart to the way of the sages,
is the mark of a virtuous person.
People also eagerly devote their hearts,
but it may not be to the way of the sages.
To hear and see much, and thereby understand the correct path,
is the highest understanding;
to hear and see much, and thereby understand the wrong path,
is deluded understanding.
Like the beauty of a wise person's plans,
they yield to others but follow the Way;
like the ugliness of a petty person's plans,
they bend the Way to follow others.
Someone asked: "Are there distinctions (debates) within the *Five Classics*?"
I replied:
"Only the *Five Classics* contain true distinctions (debates).
In discussing Heaven, nothing is more distinguishing than the *Classic of Changes*;
In discussing events, nothing is more clear than the *Book of Documents*;
in discussing proper conduct, nothing is more clear than the *Book of Rites*;
in discussing aspirations, nothing is more clear than the *Book of Poetry*;
in discussing principles, nothing is more clear than the *Spring and Autumn Annals*.
To abandon these, any discussion is insignificant."
The sprouting of spring trees,
a quail clinging to my hand.
Though five hundred years have passed,
the person seems still to exist.
Someone says, "The clamorous teachings are what everyone in the world talks about,
how can it be said that the person still exists?"
I say:
"That is not the case;
the world has long been without sages.
A newborn child
recognizes its own parents;
in the clamorous learning,
each follows their own teacher.
Refine and refine it,
and it will be found within."
Someone says, "Fine jade is not carved,
beautiful words are not embellished,
what does that mean?"
I say:
"If jade is not carved,
then *yu* and *fan* jade cannot be made into vessels;
if words are not embellished,
then the *dian* and *mo* documents cannot become classics."
Someone asked: "Sima Qian said,
'The *Five Classics* are not as concise as the *Laozi*.
In youth, one cannot fully grasp its changes;
throughout life, one cannot exhaust its study.'"
I replied:
"If that is so,
then the Duke of Zhou was confused, and Confucius was a villain.
In ancient times, learning involved both farming and self-sufficiency,
and in three years one mastered a single
classic.
Today's learning
is not only about elegant embellishments,
but also embroidering one's girdle
and handkerchief.
What has this to do with *Laozi* being *Laozi*?"
Someone asked: "Can the explanations of scholars be concise?"
I replied:
"They can be concise in breaking down the categories."
Someone asked: "Does a gentleman listen to music?"
I replied:
"A gentleman only listens to proper music.
That which is wild and excessive,
that which deviates from what is right,
that which is decadent and pleasurable,
a gentleman does not listen to it."
Someone asked: "Is it appropriate to serve a gentleman by playing games?"
I replied:
"When attending a sitting, one listens to his words;
"If there is wine, then observe the rites,
why bother with gambling!"
Someone said, "Are there not games of chance and chess?"
He replied:
"To engage in those is still better than doing nothing.
Is attending to a superior man better than doing nothing?
A superior man cannot be continuously attended.
Attending to a superior man:
obscures brightness,
blocks fluency,
loses possession,
shames glory,
defeats success.
How is that better than doing nothing!"
A small bird soars to the sky,
isn't it due to its six wings?
Pluck them and attach them to a dead dove,
how burdened it would be!
Thunder shakes the heavens,
wind brushes against the mountains,
clouds gather in all directions,
rain flows into the depths,
are these not their respective tasks?
Marquis Wu of Wei and Wu Qi were floating on the West River,
valuing the security of the rivers and mountains.
Qi said, "Security lies in virtue, not in fortifications."
He said:
"How beautiful are these words!"
If the ruler, in deploying his troops, were always like this,
then how could even the Grand Duke (Jiang Ziya) surpass him?
Someone asked:
"Were the nine tripods of Zhou treasures?"
He replied:
"They were material treasures.
Material treasures depend on men to be considered treasures."
From Duke Huan of Qi and Duke Wen of Jin onward,
until the unification by Qin,
there was nothing worth seeing.
Someone said, "If Qin had nothing worth seeing,
how did it achieve unification?"
He replied:
"What is meant by 'worth seeing'
is the observation of virtue.
As for observing military prowess,
since the beginning of time,
there has never been a Qin like that."
Someone asked:
"Why did Lu decline when it employed Confucians?"
He replied:
"Lu did not employ true Confucians.
In the past, when the Duke of Zhou
